title: The Promotion of Physical Activity for the Prevention of Alzheimer's Disease in Adults With Down Syndrome
description_brief: The objectives of this study are to determine the feasibility and potential efficacy of remotely delivered group exercise sessions to increase daily moderate to vigorous physical activity in adults with Down syndrome, relative to a usual care control. Participants will be randomized to attend 40 min remotely delivered group moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) sessions at low frequency (1 session/wk.,RL), high frequency (3 sessions/wk., RH), or usual care control usual care control (UC). In addition to the group MVPA sessions, participants in both the RL and RH groups will also receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk. Content for both the RL and RH arms will be identical with the exception of group session frequency (1 vs. 3/wk.). Participants in the UC arm will receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and monthly remote individual support/education).The primary aim is to Assess daily MVPA (min) in the RL, RH, and UC arms at baseline, 3, 6, 9, and 12 mos., and obtain effect sizes for change in MVPA over 12-mos.Secondary Aim 1 is to assess the impact of MVPA on cardiovascular fitness, quality of life, cognitive function, and brain parameters related to Alzheimer's Disease (whole and regional brain volume, functional connectivity, and cerebral blood flow) at baseline, 6, and 12 mos. Secondary Aim 2 will determine the feasibility (retention, session attendance, use of recorded sessions (RH/RL only) of RL, RH, and UC interventions.
description_detailed: This research study will compare 3 strategies for the delivery of an intervention to increase moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) in community dwelling adults with Down Syndrome; remotely delivered group MVPA sessions at low (1 session/wk.,RL), high frequency (3 sessions/wk., RH), or usual care control (UC). Adults (age ≥ 18 yrs.) with Down Syndrome will be randomized (2:2:1) to one of the 3 intervention arms for an 12-mo. trial. Cohorts of \~20 adults with Down Syndrome will be recruited and computer randomized. Participants will be stratified by sex and sequentially randomized by the study statistician. Participants in all arms will be provided with an iPad for intervention delivery, Fitbit for self-monitoring MPA, and will be asked to complete 150 min of MPA/wk. Participants in the RL and RH arms will be asked to complete 40 minutes MVPA sessions delivered via Zoom software on an iPad, RL will be provided 1 session/wk, and RH will be provided 3 sessions/wk. Participants in both the RL and RH groups will also receive one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk. with a heath coach to discuss progress and provide support. The UC intervention will follow the traditional approach to promote increased MVPA. Participants will receive an iPad tablet loaded with information regarding increasing MVPA and will also receive resistance bands and a Fitbit for self-monitoring MVPA. Monthly 20-min. education/support sessions, identical to the education/support sessions provided in the RL and RH arms, will be delivered to participants and their caregivers remotely on the iPad using FaceTime. All outcomes will be collected by trained research assistants who are blinded to the study condition. The primary outcome, daily MVPA (min) in the RL, RH, and UC arms will be assessed at baseline, 3, 6, 9, and 12 mos. using an accelerometer. All secondary outcomes will be assessed at baselines, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcomes are to assess the impact of MVPA across the RL, RH, and UC arms on cardiovascular fitness, quality of life, cognitive function and brain parameters related to Alzheimer's Disease (whole and regional brain volume, functional connectivity, cerebral blood flow). Additionally the researchers will determine the feasibility (retention, session attendance, use of recorded sessions (RH/RL only) and safety of RL, RH, and UC arms.

groups.title: Remote High
groups.description: Remote High: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions 3x a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

groups.title: Remote Low
groups.description: Remote Low: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions once a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

groups.title: Personal Coach
groups.description: Personal Coach: Participants will receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and monthly remote individual support/education.

groups.description: Remote High: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions 3x a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Minutes of Moderate to Vigorous Physical Activity (MVPA) Per Day
outcomeMeasures.description: MVPA was assessed using an ActiGraph tri-axial accelerometer.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Only participants who had valid accelerometer wear time (8 hrs a day for at least 3 weekdays/1weekend day) are included at each timepoint.

groups.title: Remote High
groups.description: Remote High: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions 3x a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

groups.title: Remote Low
groups.description: Remote Low: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions once a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

groups.title: Personal Coach
groups.description: Personal Coach: Participants will receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and monthly remote individual support/education.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Function
outcomeMeasures.description: Working memory, processing speed, multitasking, and episodic memory will be assessed at baseline, 6 and, and 12 months, using tests selected from the widely used Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery (CANTAB, Cambridge Cognition, LTD, Cambridge, UK) for Down syndrome. The CANTAB for Down syndrome uses a battery of tests including multitasking, episodic memory, executive function and processing speed.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cardiovascular Fitness
outcomeMeasures.description: Maximal treadmill tests (modified Balke protocol) will be completed at baseline, 6, and 12 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Quality of Life
outcomeMeasures.description: Quality of life will be assessed at baseline, 6, and 12 months with the Personal Well-Being Index Intellectual Disability, which contains 7 items, each corresponding to a quality of life domain: standard of living, health, life achievement, personal relationships, personal safety, community connectedness, and future security. Participants answer questions on a 0-4 scale, with 0 being least happy and 4 being most happy.

outcomeMeasures.title: Brain Volume
outcomeMeasures.description: Brain volume will be measured using structural MRI at baseline, 6, and 12 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Functional Connectivity
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional connectivity will be measured using resting state MRI (rsMRI) at baseline, 6, and 12 months.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cerebral Blood Flow
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional connectivity will be measured using arterial spin labeling at baseline, 6, and 12 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Retention
outcomeMeasures.description: Retention will be measured by the percentage of participants who complete the 12 month intervention, defined as completing the 12 month outcome assessments.

outcomeMeasures.title: Session Attendance
outcomeMeasures.description: Session attendance for both group MVPA and education/support sessions from baseline to 12 months will be obtained from records maintained by the health educator, and expressed as the percent of possible sessions. Attendance at group MVPA sessions will be defined as being logged in to the video conference and remaining on the screen for the entire 30-min session. Attendance at individual support/education sessions, for the both exercise and UC conditions, will be defined as answering the FaceTime call, and being present on screen for the entire session.

outcomeMeasures.title: Use of Recorded Exercise Sessions
outcomeMeasures.description: Use of recorded exercise sessions will be tracked using Dropbox which provides information on how many times each user watched a video.

outcomeMeasures.title: Reported Serious Adverse Event
outcomeMeasures.description: Safety will be measured by number of participants reporting a serious adverse event, i.e., any untoward medical occurrence that results in death, is life-threatening, requires inpatient hospitalization or results in persistent or significant disability/incapacity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Weight
outcomeMeasures.description: Weight will be measured in light clothing on a calibrated scale (Model #PS6600, Belfour, Saukville, WI) to the nearest 0.1 kg.

outcomeMeasures.title: Height
outcomeMeasures.description: Standing height will be measured with a portable stadiometer (Model #IP0955, Invicta Plastics Limited, Leicester, UK).

outcomeMeasures.title: Waist Circumference
outcomeMeasures.description: Waist circumference will be assessed using a waist tape measure.

outcomeMeasures.title: Energy Expenditure of Exercise Sessions
outcomeMeasures.description: The energy expenditure of sessions will be collected by a portable metabolic system at random timepoints across the 12 month study.

outcomeMeasures.title: Functional Lower Extremity Strength
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional lower extremity strength will be assessed using the Five Times Sit to Stand

outcomeMeasures.title: Functional Mobility
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional mobility will be assessed using the Timed Up and Go.

outcomeMeasures.title: Upper Body Strength
outcomeMeasures.description: Upper body strength will be assessed using hand grip dynamometer

outcomeMeasures.title: Activities of Daily Living
outcomeMeasures.description: Activities of daily living will be assessed using the Waisman Activities of Daily Living scale. This scale contains 17 questions, each item is rated as 0="does not do", 1="does with help", or 2="does independently / on own. A higher score indicates greater independence.

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Burden
outcomeMeasures.description: Caregiver burden will be assess using The Modified Caregiver Strain Index. The tool has 13 questions that measure strain related to care provision. Scoring is 2 points for each 'yes', 1 point for each 'sometimes', and 0 for each 'no' response. Scoring ranges from 26 to 0; a higher score indicates a higher level of caregiver strain.

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Stress
outcomeMeasures.description: Caregiver stress will be assessed by the Caregiver Self-Assessment Questionnaire. This questionnaire is 18 questions, 16 with yes or no responses, and 2 ranking questions. Typically a higher score indicates a higher level of caregiver stress.

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Quality of Life
outcomeMeasures.description: Caregiver quality of life will be assessed by the Adult Carer Quality of Life Questionnaire. The Adult Carer Quality of Life Questionnaire is a 40-item instrument that measures the overall quality of life for adult carers. Scores on the have a possible range of 0 to 120 with higher scores indicating greater quality of life.

adverseEventsModule.description: Events collected during outcome assessment appointments, before each exercise session, and during monthly health education meetings.

eventGroups.title: Remote High
eventGroups.description: Remote High: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions 3x a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

eventGroups.title: Remote Low
eventGroups.description: Remote Low: Participants will attend 40 min remotely delivered group MVPA sessions once a week, receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and one 20-min remotely delivered individual support/education session/wk.

eventGroups.title: Personal Coach
eventGroups.description: Personal Coach: Participants will receive a step counter, access to resources for increasing MVPA, and monthly remote individual support/education.

seriousEvents.notes: Transespophageal echocardiogram revealed severe mitral valve regurgitation related to congenital heart disease
Hospital admittance due to pulmonary edema cause by congestive heart failure
Emergent appendectomy due to ruptured appendix
Surgery to mitigate effects of spinal infection.
Surgery to mitigate the effects of previous isthmus spondylolisthesis.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a remotely delivered group exercise / physical activity program (moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, MVPA) with supportive tools (step counter/Fitbit, iPad, education/support sessions) intended to increase daily MVPA and assess downstream effects on fitness, cognition and brain measures related to Alzheimer's disease. This is a behavioral/lifestyle intervention, not a pharmacologic agent. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act (key trial details extracted): The trial titled "The Promotion of Physical Activity for the Prevention of Alzheimer's Disease in Adults With Down Syndrome" (ClinicalTrials.gov NCT04048759) randomized adults with Down syndrome to remote low-frequency (1x/week) or high-frequency (3x/week) 40‑min group MVPA sessions vs usual care; all arms received activity monitors and education/support. Primary outcome: daily MVPA (minutes/day); secondary outcomes include cardiovascular fitness, quality of life, cognitive function and brain parameters (volume, connectivity, cerebral blood flow). No drug or biologic is listed as an intervention. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — per the provided category definitions, this trial does not test a biologic (monoclonal antibody/vaccine), a small molecule targeting AD pathology, a pharmacologic cognitive enhancer, or an intervention targeting neuropsychiatric symptoms. It is a non‑pharmacologic, behavioral prevention/intervention trial (exercise), so it does not fit into the four drug/symptom categories and is therefore classified as 'N/A'. The published results and protocol confirm the above. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Web search sources used (selected): 1) ClinicalTrials.gov summary for NCT04048759 (trial details, arms, outcomes). citeturn0search2 2) Full published trial report: Ptomey et al., "The promotion of physical activity for use in Alzheimer's disease prevention trials in adults with Down syndrome: Results from a 12‑month randomized trial" (Alzheimer's & Dementia: TRCI / PMC full text). citeturn0search1turn0search0 3) Rationale/design paper for the 12‑month randomized trial (Contemp Clin Trials Commun). citeturn0search3
